III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The agency is sited in a leased office space located on Telegraph Road in Pontiac,
Michigan. The agency has utilized this office space as a satellite office for many years;
and it is very spacious with ample room for staff, and clients. There are several
individual offices for program staff, therapists, technical support staff, and client
visitation. There are attractively decorated visitation rooms, a therapy room, and outer
waiting areas with an abundant of sitting, as well as, a concession/coffee area, several
closets for storage, a large conference room, and training area. Client and employee
files are locked and stored in a secure area. Fire extinguishers are located in the
building and there are several exit signs and direction for building evacuation. The
office is situated in a commercial strip-mall location, and sufficient parking is available
for both clients and staff.
B. Program Description
The agency will provide foster home certification, foster care, and adoption services;
and has it has applicable program statements and policies and procedure for all.
2

The Foster Home Certification component will recruit foster homes for children birth
through seventeen years of age, with a variety of issues and special needs, inclusive of
foster homes for sibling groups and teens. The agency will recruit, train, and provide
certification services for foster homes located in, Oakland, Macomb, and Wayne
counties, as well as counties, where a foster child’s family may have originated at the
time of the child ‘s foster care placement, such as Genesee, or Livingston county, or
etc..
The Foster Care program will provide placement and supervision services to children
from birth to nineteen year of age, who displays a variety of needs, from general needs
to behavioral and emotional difficulties. The agency will employ a continuum of foster
care services to address the child and his or her family’s issues; including behavior
modification and therapy. The agency will work with the child, his or her family, the
courts, Department of Humans Services, and other agencies, individuals, and entities,
towards meeting a goal of permanency for the child.
The Adoption program will evaluate, educate and train applicants for adoption, prepare
and place children in adoptive homes, and will supervise adoptive placements, as
necessary and or required. Adoption services will be provided to children from infancy
to age eighteen, of either gender and of all cultural background; who are placed in the
agency’s foster care system or who may be referred to the agency by their contractor,
or another agency, inclusive of the Michigan Adoption Resource Exchange (MARE).
The agency will not provide services for direct consent or international adoptions.
The agency’s policies and procedures have been reviewed, and have been found to be
in complaint with applicable rules and statutes. The agency will operate with a Chief
Administrator, Senior Vice President, Program Director, Director of Adoptions, Foster
Care Supervisor, Adoption Supervisor, Certification Supervisor, five Foster Care Case
Managers, three Adoption Specialists, two Certification Specialists, an Administrative
Assistant, and Receptionist. All staff is in place, and employee records have been
reviewed.
From a financially perspective, the agency will function under Ennis Center for Children,
Inc.’s overall budgetary structure, and financial data was reviewed, and there are no
concerns in this area. The agency has a contract with the Department of Human
Services, and will receive per diems rates for children placed in foster care and
payments for adoption completions.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
There are not violations.
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
The issuance of a provisional license for a private child placing agency is
